FacilityName: Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP - Cedar Bayou

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chevron Phillips Cedar Bayou facility (Cedar Bayou) is a subsidiary of Chevron Phillips Chemical Company, LP, headquartered in The Woodlands, Texas.  The Cedar Bayou Plant is located on the North side of Interstate 10 between Cedar Bayou and Sjolander, and is situated on approximately 1,000 acres.  The plant was initially built by Gulf Oil and began operating in 1963.  In 1984, it became part of Chevron through the Chevron-Gulf merger, and is currently part of the Chevron Phillips Chemical Company, LP, as the result of a joint venture.

The basic business of Cedar Bayou is to produce simple olefins, which include ethylene and propylene, and derivatives which include polyethylene resins, normal alpha olefins, and polyalphaolefins.  These products are primarily ?intermediates? which are processed further by our customers to produce finished consumer products.  End uses for our products include: plastics and packaging, biodegradable detergents, synthetic lubes and hydraulic fluids, and waxes.  Chemicals used at the facility that exceed the RMP threshold quantity include flammable mixtures which may contain such chemicals as; Methane, Ethylene, Butene, Hexene, Ethane, Methanol, Propane and Propylene; and toxics such as boron trifluoride, aqueous ammonia, chlorine and titanium tetrachloride.  Process PAO-1791 has been shut down and is not expected to run again.  It is currently being demolished.  Therefore, it has been removed from the RMP.

Elaboration on Accident Prevention

The Cedar Bayou facility complies with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of highly hazardous chemicals, and has applied the programs and policies found in the standard to activities throughout the entire plant.

Specific program elements include:

1. Employee Participation ? It is the policy of Cedar Bayou to seek participation of employees at all levels in establishing procedures and practices that govern Health, Safety and Environmental issues (Fire & Safety Guideline (FSG)

e trailer at a time; providing video camera surveillance of the tube trailer area; remote operated valves to isolate the trailer and reduce the amount released; manual BF3 alarms in the unit to notify personnel in the immediate area of a release; and a water deluge system with remote activation to minimize the release footprint (BF3 is drawn to water).  A large capacity truck is used to minimize tubing connections and to decrease truck traffic on roadways.

Chemical specific preventions for titanium tetrachloride toxic OCAs include: an operator in attendance during the entire titanium tetrachloride unloading process can isolate the system remotely while the catalyst supervisor audits the unloading process.  Unloading hoses are designed for a higher pressure service than the system would normally require.  These stainless steel braided hoses are provided with additional support to prevent unnecessary binding or crimping.  When not in use, the hoses remain hooked up under nitrogen pressure to prevent moisture from degrading the hose integrity.

Chemical specific preventions for chlorine toxic OCAs include: replacing the transfer hose every year (the hose is hastelloy with a Teflon lining with a five year estimated life).  There are four chlorine sensors located at all four quadrants of the chlorine cylinder pad.  The detectors alarm at 3 ppm and initiate a chlorine alarm in the local control room.  In addition, lights flash and horns sound in the area of the chlorine cylinders.  An automatic shut-off valve is mounted on the chlorine cylinder after installing the hose during change-out of the cylinder.  The valve will close automatically if there is a chlorine leak detected.  The valve can also be manually closed from the WT control room for the cooling tower chlorine cylinder and from the Main Utilities control room for the clarifier cylinder.  The valve is tested each time a cylinder is changed.  After changing the cylinder, all connections are checked for leaks. Onl

y one cylinder is connected to the supply header at each location at one time.  Cylinders are connected at the vapor valve and not the liquid valve.  Vapor releases would be smaller than liquid releases.  Cylinders have been located outside of areas with fire threat potential, and are protected against vehicle impact.

Aqueous ammonia replaced anhydrous ammonia in this facility as an inherently safer alternative chemical.  The smaller release footprint obtained from aqueous ammonia does not make if off-site.   Chemical specific preventions for aqueous ammonia toxic OCAs include:  the containment basin is designed for full volume release; the tank vent space is vented back to the delivery truck during unloading process to minimize air emissions; and an operator is in attendance during unloading operation and can block in the truck if needed.  The ammonia tank is filled by an overhead line with a dip tube into the vessel.  A manual alarm on the unit is used to notify personnel in the immediate area of a release. 

ELABORATION ON EMERGENCY RESPONSE

ALARM SYSTEMS: Cedar Bayou has an internal plant wide alarm system for fires and emergencies.  In addition, the Baytown alarm system can be activated in the event of incidents with potential offsite consequences.

TRAINED EMERGENCY RESPONDERS:  To protect onsite workers and property, Cedar Bayou has fully trained volunteer responders covering all four rotating shifts to ensure 24-hour coverage.  Each shift has a Fire & Safety Specialist, ten Fire Brigade members, and three Emergency Medical Service/Rescue members.  ERT members receive training in all recognized categories of response (Fire, Haz-Mat, Emergency Medical Treatment, Rescue and Environmental Protection).  The ERT has won several championships at International Rescue & Emergency Care Association competitions.   

COMMUNICATIONS LINK TO OFFSITE RESPONDERS:  The Cedar Bayou Emergency Operations Center (EOC) is the central communication point for internal and externa

l responders.  The EOC is staffed by Environmental, Health & Safety personnel, as well as individuals who are on call, per the facility Incident Command System.  The City of Baytown emergency assistance is obtained by calling 911.  Industry assistance is also available through the mutual aid groups listed below.  The plant Safety Supervisor participates with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  In 1988, Cedar Bayou initially shared release scenario information with the LEPC.  This Risk Management Program information has since been used to update release scenarios.

MOBILE FIRE PROTECTION EQUIPMENT

(1) Mobile Emergency Command Post
(2) E-One 2,000 gpm Foam Pumper with 75 ft aerial ladder
(3) 2,000 gpm Foam Pumper carrying 500 gallons of foam and 500 gallons of water.
(4) One-Ton Fire Truck with 250 gallons of foam solution.  A foam trailer with 1,000 gallons of foam is also available.
(5) ?-Ton Ford Fire Truck with equipment trailer (includes 4 additional Scott Air Packs with extra breathing air bottles, 1 Resuscitator with refill, 2 mutual aid radios, 400 ft of 1-1/2? fire hose, and 200 ft of 2-1/2? fire hose).
(6) A fully equipped ambulance placed in service in 2005.
(7)  A plant fire water system with ground-level and elevated fire monitors.  

MEMBERS OF MUTUAL AID GROUPS WITH OTHER PLANTS

Cedar Bayou is a member of both the Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) and Mutual Aid of Mont Belvieu (MAMB).  CIMA and MAMB offer additional emergency response assistance if on-site responders and equipment can not handle an emergency.  The EOC has the authority to request assistance from outside mutual aid groups.  Cedar Bayou also offers assistance through the mutual aid groups to offsite emergencies.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

On-Site Accidents
 
There have been two on-site accidents in the last five years involving chemicals that are on the 40 CFR PART 68.130 List of Substances:

09/05/2003 ? UTIL-1092; a contractor employee was exposed to aqueous ammonia

when traversing a pipe rack while conducting an inspection of new piping.  The contractor's harness caught on a ? turn ball valve and opened it.  The contractor was sprayed across the lower back and received burns across the back, buttocks and thighs.

11/01/2006 ? PAO-1795; a flash fire occurred when hydrogen was released to the atmosphere during an attempt to clear debris from piping.  An employee was burned by the flash fire and received minor first aid.  Minimal equipment damage occurred.

Off-Site Accidents

There were no off-site accidents in the last five years involving chemicals that are on the 40 CFR PART 68.130 List of Substances.
